name: Only If
description: Only If is a surreal first person adventure-puzzle game. You play as Anthony Clyde, who, after a heavy night of partying, wakes up to find himself in an unfamiliar bed with no memory of the previous night's events.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP (SP2 or higher), Vista, 7, or 8 Processor: Dual Core CPU @ 2.2 GHz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Nvidia GeForce 8800 GT / ATI Radeon HD 4770 DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 1 GB available space Sound Card: DirectX 9.0c compatible
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or 8 Processor: Dual Core CPU @ 2.4 GHz Memory: 3 GB RAM Graphics: Nvidia GeForce GTX 280 / ATI Radeon HD 5830 Storage: 2 GB available space Sound Card: DirectX 9.0c compatible

reviews.review_text: So after playing this game for quite some time and giving it a chance by finishing it i got 2 conclusions:  1) The reviewers giving it a bad review don't have a clue what they're talking about and they don't care about the genre of the game. Probably teenagers or people hating adventure/indie games.  2) This is a great game in all aspects. I agree it's getting a little frustrating at times and it that it has its bugs, but hey, which adventure game didn't have these things? You have to keep in mind that this is a free game (surprisingly), and it gives you the chance to spend some hours gaming happily (if you like the genre).   This game is a hybrid of adventure/indie/mystery games. And the voice acting is awesome despite the bad comments i've been seeing around. Reminds me a bit of myst combined with the craziness of stanley parable.  I strongly suggest this game if you 're into mystery/atmospheric games and like playing through a story.  ---UPDATE---- I'm sorry if I offended a general group of people, certainly wasn't aiming for that. About the teenagers part, i said 'probably' and what I was trying to say is that a big percent of the teenagers can't appreciate this game properly, hence the bad reviews about things in this game i found prety interesting and amazing. I never said this game is perfect or doesnt have problems, i just recommended it and found the devs work really good for a free indie game.  About the incoherent jumbled mess of the story,I just love how abstract this game is, it draws you in and u have to think on your own what the hell is going on, just like reading a well-written book.  In the forums you can find alot of very logical and good explanations regarding the story, that make sense.

For free you could definitely do worse. The message is pretty cool and it also has some interesting mechanics and good/bad design. It helped me think about how to design videogames to accomplish goals and convey things to the player as well as different mechanical ideas.
Only If there was a Review...

'Avoid, If at all possible.' The words of Douglas Adams are to be headed here. This game disregards all standards of gameplay and player psychology, and punishes the player for not being able to read the creator's mind. You will find yourself unable to complete a section over and over again. Not because you are bad at the game, but because the game never taught you any basic mechanics.  Do NOT be fooled. This is NOT a puzzle game. There are no puzzles here.

I'm gonna be honest, a few levels are utter trash. The movement is pretty bad. But the ending. Dear god the ending.  That was amazing. You have to suffer a bunch of it, and some of the riddles are vague. But you know what. The ending is great. Like I was satisfied that that was the ending. And I am a cynical bitter sadistic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who hates everything.
Graphics and voice acting are great. Puzzles are mostly amusing, but irritating at times. Can't say much about the story itself but it is an interesting game to play through at least once.

This game is basically a forum troll in game form: something terrible and without merit that is trying to get attention it doesn't deserve.  The game: The controls are terrible and later in the game they introduce platforming that you have to get through to proceed, using those same atrocious controls. Imagine precision jumping on tiny platforms, in floaty 3D environments, with sloppy tank controls. Also you can't see your feet, or your shadow. Every landing is a guess, and sometimes platforms just drop you anyway if you're too close to the edge.  The narrator: The on again/off again narrator is verbally abusive throughout, offers no insight, and is just annoying every time he chimes in. He's basically just there to threaten to kill you if you don't play along. That's it. No wit, no humor, no insight, no point.  Level design: The levels don't take the game's own setting into account and the level design just devolves and gets lazier the further you go, and the 'twist' at the end reveals that you never left reality, so those 'lazy dream world' levels make no sense.   The plot: The entire story, if one can call it that, is just an immature and juvenile mess. It is revealed in its entirety at the end of the game, in the visually deprived ending sequence. By this I don't mean you are lead down a trail of hints to piece everything together at the end. No, you are just lead through levels at literal gun point and told the story ONLY when you reach the end of the game. And it's not worth the effort. It's sloppy writing the likes of a 15 year old trying to be edgy would write. You're just some dude and your girlfriend's step father kidnaps you, puts you through hell(somehow), all because apparently, you and your girlfriend are blood relatives... He kidnapped someone, held them captive against their will, threatened their lives (and murder them if you take into account the fact he kills you if you fail any of the badly laid out task he throws at you, some of which are entirely based on GUESSING.) and his reason is 'I didn't want you to have sex with your sister'... then how about just telling him they are related? In fact, she girl chimes in and says she just found out and was going to tell you, but her step dad kidnapped you first.   What was even the point.

Only If I wasn't so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ curious to see what this game was.  'Only If', a first person adventure game. I really don't know what add to this. I guess they tried to make a game like 'Stanley Parable' or 'Gone Home': you walk around, solving 'puzzles' and understanding more and more the plot. What's the problem here? The plot. I couldn't understand a thing, maybe I got 10% of all this. I have no idea of what they planned to make us think, but.. look, I seriously have nothing to work with here.  You are some guy who goes to a party, and after something happens (apparently they're not good enough to create a party scene) you find yourself in a bedroom. You wake up, and some weird black fog, maybe the same one from Lost, makes you faint again. After a while you meet this not-so-friendly voice from a radio, that will escort you through the game.  Already after 5 minutes into the game, I saw some major problems: the voice acting was one. I can clearly hear that they were trying pretty hard to make it look like a normal converstation. I admit it, sometimes it kinda worked, but for most of it, it was.. odd. Expecially 'cause the guy from the radio haves this stereotypical black man voice, even tho' probably the voice actor wasn't even a black man (I can't prove it). Another problem were the puzzles: apparently this game haves some kind of puzzles. What's the problem with them? You don't even know where to start. Sometimes they don't even give you a clue, sometimes they throw you random information that you can't use. I had to look up through a walkthrough bunch of time to understand what was goin on.  After a very little while, you have to choose what pawn to pick from a chessboard: white or black. From what you choose, you'll get a totally different ending, but also a different 'game'.  The white pawn was.. I dunno. Enjoyable, I guess? It was weird, still kinda bad, and had no explanation, but for some weird reason, I enjoyed it. Maybe because the gameplay was still the same one from the intro, easy and weird at the same time. I found myself doing the most weird things during this gameplay. I won't spoil them, but man, that was odd. But you know what? I felt like I was watching one of those B movies. You know the one, the movie that is so terribly written, with horrible acting and impractical montage. The one that you know it's terrible, but you have to finish it, because you're actually enjoying it. Same goes for the final of this: weird, totally not self-explaining and almost made no sense. I was kinda happy with it.  Then I played the black pawn ending. By god, why did I had to. I actually didn't even finished it because ITS ♥♥♥♥ING IMPOSSIBLE. I'm not joking around, the game suddently turns from goofy random puzzles to survival 'horror'. Is like Amnesia, but bad. Really, really bad. And impossible. Expecially 'cause there is a straight line to follow, but guess what, there is NOTHING THAT EXPLAINS YOU WHERE TO GO. And if you don't follow the line? Game over man, start from last checkpoint, that maybe is really far away from where you was. I couldn't finish that ending cause even the playthought was so clueless that didn't gave me any sign of what the hell to do next. I gave up.  The graphic is pretty good, even thought some texture looks really horrible. Well, it is Unity. And the soundtrack is almost absent, probably some songs got from youtube users.   So, what do we get in the end? A free game on Steam that makes no sense, it's badly written and gives no lession whatsoever. But I enjoyed my time with it.  Final Score: a Pot/10  TL;DR  Is it bad? Kinda. Should I play this? Yes. But just don't pick the black pawn.  PS: ACHIEVEMENT MEMAS LOOOOL :-) please crawl back into your hole.

+ Fantastic visuals + Funny, quality voice-acting + Some of the puzzles actually become quite difficult  - Like others, I had a bug or two with the achievements, but they seem to be working properly now - Very short
This game has had my most favourite ending achievement yet

How a puzzle works: A goal is outlined or suggested and either the tools are provided for you to utilise to reach the goal, or you are left to discover the tools for yourself in order to reach the goal.  'Only If' doesn't provide you with a goal or direction of any kind and just plonks you down in a burning field while making you hammer E every 5 seconds, then resets you back to a point because you've apparently gone the wrong way when the game hasn't given you any suggestion at all where or why you're supposed to be going.  This game is a waste of life, go play Minesweeper or Sudoku or Mahjong or literally any other game in existence.

The game has some very awesome and surreal enviroments. That's about all I can recommend for it.  The character you play as, Anthony, has horrible dialogue and a terrible voice actor that brings you out of the experience. The jumping and collision mechanics will anger even the most patient gamer. And don't play this game if you get motion sickness at all.  Maybe worth a shot since it's Free to Play, but don't go out of your way to finish the game.

Reluctant thumbs up on this strange indie studio entry. Another reviewer mentioned that this game had some influences from The Stanley Parable, and I think that's the closest experience that players can find to this game. The difference for Only If is that the puzzles, such as they are, are a bit more rudimentary, or unpolished. Many solutions are hidden from the player until they explore their environment fully (sometimes even using disappearing objects or disappearing walls to do the job)  One scene in particular has the player pressing E repeatedly to keep from blacking out or falling into 'darkness'. But the player isn't given any instructions other than that. So I spent at least 10 tries of trying to explore my environment (as the game encouraged me to do all along) and ending up running head first into a blackout. Eventually I saw that spamming the button and running straight through one particular part seemed to be the only way to succeed at the scene. I'm glad I stuck with the game, because it has some stylish scenes and setpieces, but the frustration was close to souring the whole thing for me.  Story wise, the game tries for a very young, hip aesthetic, with snarky comments from the game's antagonist intended to make the player laugh as they're given ambiguous or frustrating instructions. After a couple of full playthroughs, I was honestly exhausted from all the wisecracks and reloads that the game threw at me, and glad it was finally over. But I enjoyed the genuine surprises the game threw at me as well, so I found it was worth playing, especially since I didn't have to pay for it.

great game, small but beatufiul

I haven't gotten to the end yet, so I'm not sure if the ending is worth a change in my review. I'll edit this review when I get to the end, but for now I have to comment on this title's bizarre gameplay.  Other negative reviewers have basically taken the words out of my mouth... It's certainly not an intuitive game, it's difficult to manuever in and more times than not, it is frustrating instead of enjoyable. Trust me, I really tried to like this game. I would tell myself that the fun was in the exploration, and to an extent, it is. This game is gorgeous. If you accepted the notion that you weren't going to have much success in completing the tasks, you could enjoy it. But one can only do that for so long and for all this game's faults, it's very suspenseful, and you'll be frustrated by your lack of progression. I've played a number of games where the game leaves very cryptic clues and you have to figure out what to do next. If you don't like these games, you'll absolutely hate this one, because it's even more cryptic than most. The clues disappear   (such as in the room with the bowl you drink from, the paintings turn into verbal clues, but only for a few seconds)   or sometimes leave you searching for a long time, or perhaps if you don't follow the directions exactly so, you'll misstep and lose your direction entirely. I barely had the patience for it, and I was interested in the storyline! If the storyline seems too pretentious or you just don't care for it, you won't enjoy this game.  Pros: -Beautiful graphics -Suspenseful/compelling story -Sometimes makes you think (a little)  Cons: -Jittery camera -Cryptic clues -Excessive/nonsensical swearing (And I love to ♥♥♥♥ing swear!) -Weird audio effects (hint: don't be too far from the radio or you won't be able to hear it anymore) -Achievements don't work   Basically, if you like pretty graphics or maybe want to think a little out of the box, this game might be good for you. But there are other games that can accomplish this without being so broken. Instead, how about watching a decent walkthrough?

Kinda fun but is not scary unless you are scared of your own shadow Vinny is funny to be honest, I do enjoy his conversation  However, I hate that you cannot pause the game properly, it will run in the background. A game where you wake up after a party, you're a bit messed up, and there is an unseen person that talks to you and seems to be in control of the house; bad things happen; involves a mix of paranormal and plain serial-killer pupeteer stuff going on. You try to solve puzzles, riddles, and find things in the environment to get you to the next 'level', and ocasionally run away and hide from danger. It would be interesting, if it worked.   Here are some complaints:  I checked the controls before playing (it got that Unity configuration screen on launch), but the game kept throwing new ones at me as I played.  Voices are often too low and mumbly; but if I turn the volume up to be able to hear them, there some sounds that are too loud, and I still can't make what is being said some times.  It is glitchy, but not in the artsy sense; I kept getting stuck in some places, it was too easilly to accidentally get outside some the areas that the game expected me to remain inside and hard to find my way back to where the scritpted events would get trigger to move the game onwards; in some places there was not enough feedback on whether I was doing the right thing and but the game was simply too hard to get right or if I was actually stumbling on a glitch of the game (but after trying many different alternatives, in at least one case I realized it was not my fault; later I stopped playing after reaching a point where I don't know if I'm wasting my time bashing my head against a glitch or if I've just not figured out how to make the puzzle work yet).   Ocasional fast repetitive key-pressing; I almost couldn't get past certain spots because it required the same keys to be pressed over and over again extremely fast.   Password based 'saving'; you need to memorize (and in some cases guess first) the level name you wanna come back to if you don't wanna start from the very beginning. Dying while playing just brings you back to an earlier point most of the time; but you ocasionally have to endure an first-person cutscene everytime at certain points.   If you don't mind all these issues, then yes, I recommend this game.

I like this game.   Even though that i ragequitted 24 times in just one map in this game, it still really good.   The voice acting, the graphics and the way that they tell you the story of the game is amazing.   I'm also surprised that this game is free too.

This game ho ho this game. This game here is a perfect simulator of monotonous clunky gameplay. From unavoidable stabbing incidents to incredibly poor conveyance and structure all the way to never ending (unskipable) cutscenes. The game either gives you absolutely no clue as to what you are supposed to be doing, or beats you over the head with 'cryptic' clues, which essentially amount to 'do this dummy.' And it is neverending.   The thing has a grand total of like six button controls wasd and m1+2 add in pause menu and were all good here. The only character who's voice can be tolerated for more than a few seconds is Andrew's but he never shuts up! Seriously, from his point of view he's been kidnapped and he constantly makes decisions to his apparently malevolent all powerful omnipresent kidnapper that no sane person would ever make.  And the cutscenes, dear god the cutscenes. Each and every one of them is long and boring and essentially pointless. They don't further any story and provide loosely contrived reasons for anything that's going on. And you cannot skip them. You have to watch them every time you die SO BUCKLE UP! You are going to die a lot. And oh ho ho do I mean a lot, hoo boy. So get used to those cutscenes. ANd no there's no checkpoints per level, what do you expect? Actual gamedesign? Even if you know where something is from having died before (or having to restart the entire game to pick the new path) you have to sit through the entire thing. Over and over again. And you die. Rinse Wash and you get the picture.  There is one level with a checkpoint ONE!!! and no if you quit and type in the level name you don't start at that checkpoint either. And it starts you in the middle of a parkour section with completely out of the blue and yu will accidentaly jump off. The shooting mechanics in this portion are also shotty if that at best until the targets become so big that you'd have to look the other way to miss. Again 'do this dummy.'  No I do not reccomend this game. I only spent two hours on the thing anad it's free, and somehow I still feel like I've been cheated. I want my money back on this purchase and I spent nothing on it.   Overall I'd say it's a waste of hardrive space.

It's fun, funny, and free. There's literally no reason to at least TRY this game. The puzzles are a little tough, but they're interesting enough. There's some pretty unique mechanics in here that I haven't really seen done before. It's short, and as a result I can't think of a single time where a puzzle is repeated (except once, but you can't really call it much of a puzzle and it's for the story) so I'd say it's pretty good value for the 0 dollars you've spent. There's also some anime pictures. I don't know why. Doesn't that infringe on copyright? I guess it might not matter since they aren't profiting off it, so eh, whatever. I look forward to any other games made by these guys.

I'm really sorry, I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution has done nothing for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress I still just simply didn't find the gameplay itself fun. It also completely lacks a pause button, or if it does have one I never found it. Considering that a lot of sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is a lot more cut scene than it is game, and I end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot. I may come back to this game some other time for another shot, but at least as of now, it's left a very bad taste in my mouth.

Only If is a very surreal experience. You play as an average joe named Anthony. You were invited to a party. You get totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥d at said party. You wake up in a strange house, with a strange man talking to you through a radio. You wander through corridors, abandoned houses, and surreal dreamscapes. The game is very similar to the Stanley Parable gameplay-wise. Only If was constructed entirely on the Unity engine, and it is hands down the best looking game I've ever seen come out of that engine.  Only If's main downside is the lack of replayability. In the Stanley Parable, you have several interesting and varied endings that you can receive, all of which are based on your decisions made during the gameplay. In Only If, there are two endings, and the ending you get is based on one decision made fairly early into the game. I really wish the developers took a more complicated and versatile approach to the game's endings, because one of the endings is, albeit hilarious, really immature.   Overall, Only If is a very good game, and a very interesting experience for a free to play game. I recommend you give it a try.  OVERALL RATING: 8.75/10       ...  Perhaps it's time to wake up.  ...

Only If is a very surreal experience. You play as an average joe named Anthony. You were invited to a party. You get totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥d at said party. You wake up in a strange house, with a strange man talking to you through a radio. You wander through corridors, abandoned houses, and surreal dreamscapes. The game is very similar to the Stanley Parable gameplay-wise. Only If was constructed entirely on the Unity engine, and it is hands down the best looking game I've ever seen come out of that engine.  Only If's main downside is the lack of replayability. In the Stanley Parable, you have several interesting and varied endings that you can receive, all of which are based on your decisions made during the gameplay. In Only If, there are two endings, and the ending you get is based on one decision made fairly early into the game. I really wish the developers took a more complicated and versatile approach to the game's endings, because one of the endings is, albeit hilarious, really immature.   Overall, Only If is a very good game, and a very interesting experience for a free to play game. I recommend you give it a try.  OVERALL RATING: 8.75/10       ...  Perhaps it's time to wake up.  ...

Only If is a first person puzzle game devoloped by Creability on the Unity Engine, in which you go to a birthday party with the hopes of getting  it OOONNNN  with your crush. You wake up in her bedroom after the party, and make an attempt to leave the house, guided by a short tempered voice on a radio.  Only If is NOT a very good game. The puzzles in the game are contrived at best and straight up broken at worst. The controls are alright when all you do is explore, but they aren't very helpful for precision platforming on flying painting or giant gold pillars.   The voice acting on the radio character is actually rather good, it has a decent amount of character, but some unrealized motivation. The main character's voice is not very good however, sounding cheesy and stilted. It doesn't help that the main character is pretty much just a horrible person, which could be used as a charcter study, or even a simple moral, but all it builds up to is a frankly weak ending that's comepletely irrelevant to the themes already presented.  The whole gimick of Only If is that the world can change around you as you solve puzzles. And this is alright, but it's never really used to make intersting puzzles, the creators instead care more about confusing the player. I will admit that the puzzles tend to have an atmosphere of oddity that I assume the creators were going for. The ways things play out usually is pretty intersting, leaving me quiet for most of the gameplay. But that doesn't excuse how broken the rest of the execution is!  Overall, Only If is an unplayable game. It has some interesting ideas that never go anywhere, unused potential that could have been great, and shoddily done voice acting. But hey, at least the games pretty to look at.

If you're looking for a decent story to follow and something profound to reflect on, I would steer clear of this game. The writing is poor yet tries desperately to appear deeply introspective, the characters are shallow, and the ending falls into a deus ex machina to clean up it's many loose ends, yet still does a terrible job of it all-the-while. I also found it hard to sympathize with the protagonist due to his use of homophobic and sexist slurs. Don't get me wrong--I can see the value of of doing this to build character and chart growth and development (or lack there of) for the sake of the story line, so I really did withhold my judgement until the end. But upon reaching that point, I was left dissappointed and unimpressed with his 'moral repertoire'. Instead, the insults felt thrown in there without intention, which seems to normalize their usage instead of providing any context to the already suffering plot.  That being said, the graphics are impressive (especially for an inde title) and some of the puzzles were fun, though I felt like I had done them before in other games... But neither of these things were able to overcome my chagrin for the poor writing. A lot of people seem to have a 'wtf' reaction to this game, and if that is a reward in-it-of-itself you'd be interested in, then give it a try. But if you hope to find substance in this quagmire of random philosophy references and juvenile humor, you'll be disappointed.

I don't know what to think. I played the game through to the end and the ending was well, awful. It was a really random non sequitur joke and then a goofy song plays and everyone slaps their knees and I'm just sat here confused and unsatisfied like I just got told the longest joke in the world and the punchline makes no sense. For a narrative driven game, to end on such a low note is really really bad. If you intend to play this game, don't go in to it for the plot because nothing will ever be answered, and trust me, it's not that you can't figure it out, it's that there genuinely are no answers. The developers themselves probably don't ahve an answer, and that's not a good thing.  The puzzles are ok, although some are tedious. They're enjoyable the first time, but after finding out the surreal coating of the game is a complete sham then there's not much point to them, and late in the game they get really really really REALLY tedious. You don't feel clever for solving them, you just veel like oh my god did you really just make me shoot 100 vases.  Oh yeah, and one big problem is the fact that the audio mixing is horrible. The radio is painful to listen to and, trust me, you'll hear it a lot, while hte main character himself is really quiet. Aside from that, the voice actors themselves are really unclear in what they're saying, and there's no subtitles option. It's certainly a unique game, but it's an unsatisfying one and I feel more like the unique part of it is just the developers trying to disguise that they don't know what they're doing.

For a free game, this is a must play! (I don't agree with the tag horror btw. Strange and mysterious, but not frightening)  It is actually brilliant! Yes, it has some problems, but if you are willing to get pass those, the experience is great. You could always look at a walk-through if you are completely stuck, but I encourage you not to. The game is not difficult, just a little odd at times, but that is also a good thing. Don't expect the same ol... This game goes deep.  What really excels, is the music, sound and voice acting. Yes, there are some problems with the mix, making it hard to hear at times (headphones highly recommended) but I am really impressed with the overall quality, especially the music, being a composer myself. I would say that it is as good as an AAA-title in that regard, and I'm surprised there is so much fine work within a free title.  At times, the game is frustrating and confusing. You end up repeating some parts, especially the beginning. But I also believe that some of these frustrating parts are part of the game-play, not just bad design.  The puzzles in the game become an experience itself, rather than just something to complete in order to progress. It is dream-like and mysterious. I found the ending has little to do with the real message of the game, and it felt it was put there to have a sense of competion. I encourage you to find your own meaning in the game instead though. It will leave you reflectinging for a while, and it is great when I game can do that.  I wish for more games like this, where you don't know what is going on, where you are in for a fresh experience with no handholding.

The black pawn however, does not. The beginning makes little sense, there is no puzzle here, you just have to figure out what the game wants you to do. I also managed to screw myself in the black pawn scenario because I missed something and then passed a point of no return. I would be okay with this in some situations (ever play Maniac Mansion?), but, I spent 30minutes running around before deciding there is nothing I can do, opened a walkthrough, to find there is indeed nothing I can do.  I recommend playing this, and not even touching the black pawn scenario, if I forget that existed, then its a great game. Great riddles, great ideas, like Antichamber meets Stanley Parable.

I simply cannot recomend this game to anyone, especialy if you are using a Mac. I wanted to like this game, I realy did. But I couldn't. I can't. Here are my reasons why: 1. There is a narrator who heavily swears and crudely insults you throughout the whole game. At first, it isn't such a big deal, but trust me. It gets old quick. 2. There are many glitches and bugs both gameplay and graphicaly related. 3. Plot holes. There are just too many of them. I love games with a story, and this did not deliver. 4. Character development. I was given no reason whatsoever to give a darn about any character. So I didn't. 5. No real save feature. You have to play to checkpionts, then remember the name of that check piont for the next time you play. If the devs were going to do that why wouldn't they just have a chapter list, so we could just select the chapter instead of trying to remember some key word? The game did have a few good things going for it like: 1. Entertaining graphics and affects. 2. Your character always seemed to say what you were actualy thinking. 3. There is a gun in it. That's it. It's a shame; the game had potential. However, to be worth either my time or yours, it has a LONG way to go.

I would talk about this game, if there were actually a game here. You have no real control and there is next to no immersion once you start touching the disorganized and often unresponsive controls. In a nutshell, you just keep pressing E and hope this makes some progress...maybe...hopefully...if you're lucky  I want to like this game, I really do. It has great visuals, passable dialogue, and an atmospheric stream-of-consciousness form of gameplay that in other titles (i.e. the Stanley Parable and Gone Home) has been wildly successful and has helped drive player immersion. Only If could have been something memorable. It just failed to do so and failed spectacularly.  Now, I've played some lousy games (Superman 64 and 50 Cent: Bulletproof, to name a few), but this game takes the cake and eats it...mostly because, in this day and age, when even low-budget indie games are able to successfully compete with AAA titles, this is unacceptable.  The only good thing about this 'game' is that it was free.

Okay, so I never like writing bad reviews/responses for things. Positivity is very important to me. But this was a complete waste of my time. Look, I'm familiar with the 'masculine, vaguely threatening dude gives mysterious and inscrutable tasks to you through a radio while shouting obscenities at you' and 'bizarre lateral-thinking puzzle type gameplay revolving around vague keywords' cliches of modern gaming (which I totally unironically love), but they have to lead to something. This was completely pointless. The annoying banter with your captor is utterly meaningless and the ending resolves nothing. I guess the gameplay is pretty surreal, but it's never interesting. On top of that, I was expecting a story-based type of game experience (at least for a generous definition of 'story'), but this is definitely not that. Near-constant, terribly voice-acted cursing, drug references, memes (yes, actual memes), and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 'twist ending' that had no relevance to anything previously established do not make a compelling story. This may honestly be one of the worst games I've ever engaged with. Please don't bother playing it.  And I know some people will say 'oh, but it's free!' Time is more valuable than money. I'm not criticizing it on the grounds of the engine or the limitations of a small-scale game (although the bizarrely antiquated save system did raise an eyebrow). I really liked this game - at first.   Okay if you're ready for a 'different' experience and like going in to games not knowing anything - give this a go anyway. You'll probably enjoy the experience mostly, like I did.  SPOILERS BELOW  Still reading? Ok.   If you ever got caught up in the Lost series, you will feel the same way after playing this game. (I didn't, but I hear it goes along the same way.) Stringing you along with randomness making you think 'Woah, seriously, what is going on here, I can't wait to find out!' only to find out... it's all ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The writer had no idea where it was going either - just putting random ♥♥♥♥ together to keep you guessing, not realising the only reason people are still following is because they are more and more eager to see how this comes together and makes sense. It's human nature. And when the ending is ♥♥♥♥, we legitimately feel jipped, and all of the 'intrigue' we felt before is replaced with a feeling of having wasted your time.  In the end, this game is pretty much a guy messing around in Unity, coming up with a bunch of random mini games, and loosely tying them together with 'drugs' as an excuse (how original) and then inventing the 'incest' ending hoping that the shock factor would hide the fact that this game isn't really well thought out and is just pretentious wank. It wouldn't be so bad as a mild distraction if the author didn't think he was a flipping genius... check out his blog. His next game is just more of the same.

I heard this game was a thinking game and it was free and for linux so I said what the hell. Note that I played it through with the aid of a walkthrough so that I could best get the arc of the story without the game-mechanic-interruptions that so often plague rather than propel videogame storytelling.  The ending reveals   drugs   and   incest   as the main ideas behind the whole scenario. What follows is a personal reflection that I wrote immediately after playing the game. That is to say, it is what the game made me think of,  not  what I though of the game.    Thing is though, drugs wear off with time. I understand the 'is anything even real?' agenda that the game pushed, but IRL most drug-induced hallucinations (and regular dreams too) end with time. What you do doesn't matter; it's all just a waiting game. For me, when I'm dreaming, if everything is just too absurd, I stop everything and sit down and wait for it all to blow over. And then eventually I wake up. A game like this would work for me if there was a strict time frame for the 'trip' portion of the game, and then you'd automatically become less and less drugged until you actually regained sense. Alternatively, for a non-drug-activated trip (i.e. a regular dream), there would also be a set time frame (say, 30 minutes) where the dream would occur. If you wanted to see how the dream story plays out, you'd have to either work quickly and effectively the first time through, or voluntarily fall asleep multiple times and attempt to progress further and further along the dream-storyline. This is something that actually happens in my dreams: I have recurring storylines that I revisit periodically and progress further and further in; I get better at advancing the story to where I left off with each attempt.    The concepts are as intriguing as they are blatantly lifted from source material; that is to say, it's moderately interesting, but those interesting components clearly have seen better days. If you have 2 hours (or more, if you don't want to use a walkthrough), go ahead and get this game. As a tool for getting me to think, it has succeeded. As an actual game with solid production value and replayability, this game does not meet standards.  If you absorb these sorts of psychological topics best through gaming, play this game. If you don't, don't. There are other works in different media out there that better address these concepts. If you don't want stimulating material at all, then steer clear. Normally a big fan of indie games, especially, in the adventure game genre. I heard a lot about this game so I thought I would try it out.  First off, overall, well-done visually. The park was the most detailed. I also liked the combination of text input....while non-descriptive in that I could actually type in-game...always an interesting add-on from olden tymes.  Aside from that, I think this game tried too hard. Both main voice actors were abrasive to the point of me cringing at them speaking. There was sound clipping on both on several occasions. I am not disgusted or generally annoyed by excessive cussing but I really did feel it was over the top...most of it was just too much.  The ending was anti-climatic because the music was so loud I could barely understand what they were saying. I had to go look up someone recanting the ending online. That single point demonstrates inconsistent production of sound quality combined with story driven design. If you want loud music, while voices are speaking, drop the volume of the music! Not everyone hears at the same level. I am not hard of hearing but subtitles and decreased volume on voice tracks would have really helped.  I give a nod to the developer and team for thinking of a 'different game' and strongly encourage them to try again. But to me, that 'different game' was not fun nor did I walk away with an enlightened (or puzzled or horrified) mind. If I want edgy, spunky stuff, I will go play Bad Mojo, Katamari Damacy, Jazz Punk, Sanitarium, Total Distortion, Dear Esther, Papo & Yo, Kairo, Harvester, Catherine, or Michael Jackson's Moonwalker. None of these have such an abrasive play experience and to me were really unique standing amongst the populace of indie games.

This game tries really hard to be the Stanley Parable, but ends up failling due to a few reasons.   While the puzzles are pretty decent, they are presented in a format that screams 'MESSAGE.' While I applaud a game for trying something new, trying to imbue meaning into something that is rather shallow ends up looking bad. This is especially true for the vase jumping part. It tries hard to make the vases seem like drugs, but the ingame message is that the vases are good, powerups. This relays the message: Drugs are good, without adding anything to that idea.   The worst part is the story, which revolves around Anthony and Vinny. Vinny drugs anthony and all of the story takes place in his dream. None of the continuity is explained and it becomes a mess by the end while we wonder what the ♥♥♥♥ is going on. We are supposed to like Vinny as a character based on how he is charismatic and funny, but he acts downright evil in the windmill section. Was him trying to kill you part of the dream? If so why would he act so nonchalant during the final scene. This 'it's all a dream' excuse ♥♥♥♥s with the story way too much in that you might as well ignore it and just go with it by the plays.   The splitting off part was a stupid move by the creator as it meant that a huge section was barred off from the main playthrough. Splitting resources like that for the sake of an artificial choice is stupid in triple A games and it's stupid here.  With the dumb choice forced in and the omnipotent narator it almost feels as if the creator was going for a Stanley Parable vibe. If so, then he failed. It wound up feeling just about as interesting but a hell of a lot less satisfying.  Despite the rawness of this critique I actually kind of enjoyed the game. It was interesting and varied and it tried something new with a new aesthetic that is rare from games like this. It was free to play after all, a choice I admire from the creator, and the puzzles were pretty engaging at times. I'd recommend this to a friend for the sake of having a conversation about it. It is the kind of game that invokes thinking and that's always a good thing.

Only if you want to kill a bit of time and say to yourself 'what the hell did I just play'.   I won't spoil anything in fear the game will become unbearable for you.  The plot is terrible, there is no accomplishment or point to it all that justifies the experience the protagonist is facing. There is nothing driving you to continue other than your personal curiosity and need to finish.   Word of advice, press escape in every new area to get the name of it so you're able to return to the same spot after stoping. There are no checkpoints or saves, if you quit in the middle of an area, you start over. Which albeit it, doesn't matter since they aren't too long anyway. To return to the last area you were, press space and they type out the name.   There are a few parts where you use this same type of control for instance when the voice asks you what do bees make (honey, fyi) but this method of gameplay does not develop or continue throughout.   I get where they were trying to go with the riddles or 'pun' as the voice said at one point but they don't really make you think, instead they just spell out what you have to do.   The cursing is unnecessay. The protagonists and antagonist attitudes are not merrited, there is no context for them. In their basic form (annoyance/anger) yes but not in the form they are presented (poor voice acting maybe).   The interior design is terrible but I digress. The music at the end is too loud to hear the voices properly.   With this all said however, the level of design detail and graphic are great for this caliber of game. The transitions were long but executed well, the door puzzle concepts, mazes and jumps were great and more emphasis should have been placed on them to make them more complex or at the least longer.   To summarize, the idea behind the game, design and puzzles (although could have been executed better) give player enough momentum to push through, but the lack of context for the dialogue, goal and overall point to the entire game left me wanting more. They basically had a good idea but instead of connecting everything in a way that made sense, they left the holes in place, slapped everything together and allowed us to explore. Considering it's free, I'm not complaining but if I had to rate this game, I'd give it a 2/5, it has/had potential but I'd suggest using it to kill an hour or so.

Only If is, in my opinion, one of the best free-to-play games that Steam has to offer.  PROS -nice atmosphere: every level if unique -soundtrack: goes with atmosphere. But I found the soundtrack to be pretty soothing -graphics: I didn't expect much from a game that was free-to-play, but I was astounded at the beautiful graphics, especially in the Park level. -antagonist: The man in the radio (Vinny) is an oddly likeable character. At first he was frustrating but as I kept playing I grew to really like him. Vinny is snide, cynical, and mean, but he does seem to have moments of kindness or mercy. -protagonist: Anthony is surprisingly likeable. Most FTP 'horror' games have dull, boring protags who offer little (I'm looking at you, The Forgotten Ones). However, Anthony's personality and reactions to what happen to him are relatable and make sense for a teenage boy. -puzzles: the puzzles in Only If are difficult and actually make you think, though I will admit some are very hard.  CONS -volume/voice acting: while I adored the soundtrack, it was too loud and wouldn't turn down when the characters were talking. While Anthony could be heard easily, Vinny was difficult to hear at points; hearing him is critical to the story making sense to the player. As far as I know there is not an option for subtitles either. -puzzles: while some were great, others were arduous (mostly the Blind and Immensity levels). It took me a while to figure out what was actually going on. -checkpoints: there are hardly any checkpoints; if there are, you can't see them. this makes it very frustrating when you mess up and have to start all over. -villains: it's clear that Vinny is the primary antagonist but other villains like the dark cloud just pop up randomly with no real connection to what's going on.  Overall, I give Only If a 6.5/10. Definitely worth a try!

Original, Encaptivating, Fresh!  Let's get it out of the way that the voice acting isn't very good. Also some of the puzzles are a bit abstract and can be difficult. I think these are the two main reasons people are down voting this, but I don't think that is a fair evaluation of this game, after adding in all of the strengths. Right away, you notice that the gameplay is very unique and meta. With dialouge and puzzles that break the fourth wall, but also with gameplay mechanics and visuals that inspire your imagination. I appreciate that the developers took a very out of the box route, taking a lot of influence from the 'no rules' ideaology of the film Inception.  Bottom line, if you're looking for something fresh, imaginitive, and intruiging, than take this game for a spin!

I find this game to be one adjective: Intriguing. And to be honest, that's all I can really say. Because I don't know what else to say. I can't tell you if it's good or not, I can't say if I like it, and I certainly can't tell you how to make it better. What I'm getting at is that I want to play more and more, to find out how I should-- no, how I COULD properly judge it. But I can't, because I'm afraid to. It seems like this game is against me completing it. The game is overwhelming.  It's overwhelming in the number of choices you as the player have to make, and it's overwhelming in a sense of fear. You are constantly running from this strange, unpredictable man, who totally isn't exactly like Vaas in every way (if you didn't catch the sarcasm, I'm saying he's exactly like Vaas, in every way. Not that that's a bad thing). You're also running from this darkness, which seems to pop up around every corner and only lets you pass by trial and error. I have no idea how to tell you what to do with this game. But I will say that you should play it. You should play it, because the sense of accomplishment you get after beating that one strange puzzle that made no sense that changed after you went back to the main menu is incomparable. I'm not sure if it's bugged, poorly designed, or well designed. But it will certainly make you feel two things: Stupid and scared.

I thought the game was interesting, though at times annoying/frustrating. The concept was intriguing enough to keep me playing, however sometimes the puzzles would be glitchy and cause me to restart the level. The puzzles were not too easy and at the same time not too hard. The game gives you little hidden hints throughout the levels you play on to help you through the puzzle but it does not simply give it away. The game ran fairly well except for some glitches that would cause the character to get stuck for a second or would cause certain commands to stay on the screen, which can be annoying. My only problem with the story is that at the end it answered most of the questions I had throughout the game rather than hinting at an ambiguous ending. I think with surreal games like these those kinds of things are best left to the imagination. Overall, though, I would reccommend the game because it keeps you interested, it looks beautiful, it's free, and it doesn't take very long to finish anyway.

'Only If' Only if it was your reality, you think it is at first, then you find out it isn't, It's inception, it's someone playing with your mind, making you question why the heck are you doing these crazy things you end up doing. It shows you you can do things you thought you were not able to, it makes you think what would you do to save someone you care about. Makes you think, wow some day people may end up being able to get in your head, and think these crazy things, make you do things you wouldnt want to do, just to survive, pretty much how the world works sometimes.     I enjoyed this game, I like the whole crazy inception idea, people say how its stupid because there is no storyline, and it goes off into random directions, and makes no sense... IT IS'NT SUPPOSE TO MAKE SENSE, It is like a dream you have lots of dreams, do these dreams have a reason? Does each dream you have relate to the other? No.     It can be a little confusing at times, but it really does give you hints on what you are suppose to do through out the game, which is great, compared to other games I have played where you honestly were not even given a clue to what to do next.    The tricky part of this game is where you need to type, Im not really sure what happens when you take the black pawn, but there is a clue in the room that tells you kinda that you need to type. Just a heads up you wont see what you are typing.    I also like how when it gives you the credits it continues the game play, I thought it was over, but then when the credits came up again flashing up, then back to game it ended up being over, and I was upset to see it end. It was a short game, and I enjoyed that it was a free adventure point&click type of game, you don't really find that.     If you are into these types of game it is worth playing, specially if you enjoy mystery, or mess with your head type of games (but not the scary kind D:)   ~That is all~ Hope it helps. haha :)

To put it out there I played up to the level windmill, and I found the game to be a jumbled mess. The pre-set options let the framerate for my pc to drop tremendously. My Pc is not a low ram craptop, and it still doesn't really work. Hey I don't care about the fact that I was completely lost, it only took me about 2 minutes to glitch out the first room after the black corrador. The camera is realistic but it still makes me feel like a beached whale. It looks like the character was drugged. The voice acting (what little I heard) was on the verge of bad and Ok. The progression from the first scene to the 4th or so was so substansally weird, it seems like they are unrelated. I govern my rating on the fact that most games that are mysterious or maybe psycotic still have to contain some sort of binding factor, It has to add up somehow. The worst part is the fact that a sequal is being created, while the first doesn't have vital options like subtitiles, and some sort of tutorial based off of somthing. I mean I like puzzle games and all sorts of brain benders, but completely unrelated items giving you an unsuspecting key... What the Heck, breaking all physical laws, which would make sense, if were a dream... You need some exposition, besides waking up in a bed looking at a very conspictuous anime picture. 'Only If' I knew what was actually going on.   Only If is, at its core, an 'escape the room' game while at the same time deviating from the 'find the item(s), move to next area' model. Its approach is unique, but there is quite a bit of work to be done.   The good: Barring the lack of subtitles to completely understand what's going on, being trapped by the disembodied voice of a maniac was way funnier than it should have been. The dialogue is nonsensical at certain points, but I appreciated the banter between the protagonist and his capturer. As I mentioned earlier, it's not a game where you have to collect an assortment of items and mix and match to move onwards so I appreciated that. Even though it was a bit disorientating sometimes, the surreality of it was also a big plus for me.   The bad: The main issue is the lack of 'game elements'. By this I mean that the game is played solely by ear, so to speak. There are a few instructions, like c to crouch and shift to run, but other than that you have to figure out the rest on your own. While experimenting is fun in and of itself, it is a little frustrating when you have to utterly guess at what to do next. One instance is the fact that at certain points in the game, you must type out an answer but there is no indication anywhere that keystrokes are being registered and recognized as a 'typed answer'. The platforming level is unintuitive.   There are other things I forgot to note as I played the game, but these were all the glaring pros and cons in my eyes.  I am actually glad I played this, but I wouldn't forward it to my friends as it's a bit, 'out there'? However, for a gamer looking for something different, then you found it.

Alright, well, I played this game to see if it would be fun, like any other game, but I will admit, I've spoiled by other games similar to it. Only If doesn't have the same feel to it like, let's say- the Stanley Parable, and I completely understand that they weren't going for a similar feel or gameplay even. But, they left out things that made the Stanley Parable fun.  Firstly, I feel like the motion is very very hard to watch. I'm usually really good with fast pace games- heck, I play first person shooters all the time. This game, however, made me feel like I was running in slow motion in a dream where I can't really tell what is going on. Which, again, is part of the point, but it was annoying at times. ESPECIALLY the cutscenes. And- half of the time, I wasn't sure if I was still in a cutscene or I was given control of the keys again. Now, the imagery in the game is actually very pretty. I like how the rooms and environment look. Unfortunately though, due to the movement, everytime I move my mouse, I get a sense of motion sickness and can't really see what I'm looking at. It makes parts where you're supposed to be quick about your actions seem like a blur and much more difficult than they need to be. Secondly, the sound needs to be improved. I had my volume at around medium and I still couldn't hear what the protagonist was saying sometimes. He mumbled a lot, which just bothered me a little. Though, I will give the voice actor credit, because I don't think that was his fault, but the game's sound volumes. Like- the 'antagonist' also is hard to hear sometimes, mainly because you must be right next to him to hear him. When looking around a room and being directed by his voice, it means that I have to stand perfectly still next to him until he's done speaking, or I'm going to miss something.  Thirdly, I just didn't like the quick-time events. I know some people find them more interactive in a game, but God, I couldn't stand it. It makes your vision much much more blurry (which I understand is supposed to make you disoriented, but given that I can't move normally without somewhat blurry vision to begin with...) and while you're walking it expects you to repeatedly click one button or else you die. And you have to restart from when the chapter began. I don't like having to restart a quick-time event because of me messing up another.  Oh and can we have the chapters start at gameplay, not cutscenes? If we were given the code to start again, it should mean that we've seen the beginning cutscene already. So, anyway, Only If is a game that has some technical flaws and so far I'm a not huge fan of it, but I can see where they were going with it. The storyline has... what I'll call potential, the acting is decent enough fo the game, and the environment is made actually surprisingly well. It's still a brand new game, but it needs a lot of work.  'In Only If, you will fail a lot, you will die a lot, and you will undoubtedly be confused. ' You sure got that right, game. But I don't like dying over and over and getting confused when trying to do the most basic of tasks. The first few minutes of the game shouldn't make my eyes hurt. Just saying. Oh- which is why I couldn't play more than 20 minutes by the way.  I wish I had been able to keep playing too, because it sounds like Only If might have a better storyline near the middle and end, but if I can't get into a game in the beginning because of simple game mechanics, I just can't. But, if you like this game, good for you. I can see why you might enjoy it, I guess? For me, however, I've played better games with a similar type gameplay. And this just doesn't compare at all. So, I won't recommend this, sorry.

Great idea, flawed execution.  Let me start with the pros: I love the characters, even Vinny, who I only briefly grew tired of and then loved again.  Cons: Couldn't even finish the game because one path was buggy, and the other was unclear as to what to do.  One path appears to be a quicktime event, but another review leads me to believe that this isn't true, despite what the game tells you. This may be why I couldn't finish it, and eventually quit after being booted to the beginning of the level seven times.  The other path is a puzzle of sorts, but I'm not sure what the answer is. What the radioman says changes after the first time you play the level, and there are also party supplies that disappear when you go into a sideroom. I'm about to look up what the answer to this 'puzzle' is, because everything that seems like the correct answer is either wrong, or just not being inputted correctly (the game fails to say whether you're on the right path - I assume I'm supposed to type the answers in, but there's no indication if this is right or not).  In Only If, you will fail a lot, you will die a lot, and it will not be your fault.

I hoped to be able to play something somewhere between Portal and The Stanley Parable, two games that I loved deeply. But 'Only If' can't be compared to them in any way.  'Only If' personify mediocrity, and for all I've heard and read, the only feeling it can give a player expecting a semblance of quality in gameplay or in plot is a raw disappointement. 'Only If' is tedious to play, even with a simple walk-through to actually explain what the game expected of me.   I didn't stop after the three first levels because the game was too hard a challenge, but because there was simply no point in going on. So I used the keywords to skip annoying levels, which turned out to be each single oneI would advise to check the ending with the eponimous keyword if you quickly want to get an idea of the plot. Because there isn't that much to spoil anyway, and it may save you precious minutes of your life which you could use to replay the Staneley Parable, Portal, Quantum Condrum, Q.U.B.E., or even Vitrium.  I am not sure whether 'Only If' is still in beta—that would explain why there are no option menu at all to toogle sound or fullscreen while in a run. I'm not going to criticuze the absence of proper save/load system, since the keywords system is the only think that allowed me to keep sane by skipping the lousy parts until the end to get an opinion on the game as a whole.   The good things : nothing to pay, decent graphics, good audio quality.   Now, the painful : - Loud, lousy, long-winded dialgues.  - A lot of profanity that doesn't add anything to the characters or experience.  - The concepts of subtelty, clevernes or finesse are zeroing from the very beginning to the ending. - And that means that metaphors and symbolism are touched awkwardly, and most things are pointlessly surrealist. - A loose plot-line with, in the role of the evil mastermind, a burlesque antagonist who show the IQ of a clamp and thinks his simplistic and heavy kind of humour very clever. - A pace that tries to be original, and just gives the feeling to be testing something in alpha stage.  - The Gameplay of a repetitive, nebulous, bleak thriller. - To my surprise, I found the ending even worse than the game iself. Especially the pace. The way they handled the music in an attempt to create humor with the /final revelation/ is as exasperating as a bad movie blockbuster.  Conclusion : I must admit that I have played worse games than 'Only If' here, still, I can't help but feel like I've wasted more marbles on it than what it was worth.

Now Only If is a free-to-play eight minute demo that is a surreal first-person puzzle with some platformer elements that puts you in role of Anthony Clyde who after a heavy night of partying at his female companion’s house by the name of Sam he passes out. When he comes to he has no memory of the previous night all Anthony knows is that he needs to find Sam. Upon his search Anthony comes across a voice on a radio that introduces himself as Vinnie who clearly has it in for the protagonist to point he wants to keep him in the world he created. And as far as antagonist Vinnie goes the best way to describe him as a twisted version of Jekyll and Hyde type personality.  The world in general in only if likes to trick and toy with you in the environment by implementing riddles, puzzles, choices, observation or combination, while at certain times dealing with obstacles in the environment itself in order to progress which this games does this very well in both creativity and difficulty. Also the world itself changes as you progress which some of these changes can be settle while other changes can be extreme which result in some trippy moments that will make you wonder all until the end (Is what the protagonist experiencing and hearing is real? Is it in his head? Is he dreaming? Is he even alive?). Lastly the world in only if doesn’t follow any type of rules especially when it comes to which path/choice is right or wrong (right path/choice = wrong and the wrong path/choice = right, and vice versa.) Now there is something I should point out here the path/choices are kind of on the linear side and don't really have a impact on the ending which is a little bit on the disappointing side.  Philosophe/Dialogue – Now the game takes in a mixture of serious believable philosophical quotes in the form text, while at the same time adding entertaining is the best way to describe it which comes from…you guess it Vinnie. The reason this is a strength in only if because not only how it’s set up but also how entertaining and funny hear the dialogue between Anthony and Vinnie, especially Vinnie.  Keyword Typing – Another thing that stood out was this particular feature both in the menu and the main game. Now how this feature works is by you having to type a word or phrase in order to continue from the level you left off which works fine (note: No need for spacing or upper case letters as far as I can tell. And providing you remember or wright down the name of the level.) While keyword typing in only if is interesting and unique idea and I would like to see this feature put into the full game, however I didn’t enjoyed this feature as much that I wanted to which part of the problem is that the even though I typed the correct word in the game wouldn’t register what I typed in which forced me to type the same word multiple times just to progress (thankfully though there is not to many of these in the game/demo).  Replay ability-Now there is some form of replay ability for a game like this in terms of achievements.  Ending - In my opinion the ending seems disconnected from the game itself, however does remind me of one of those hilarious/awkward/what?! punch line moments you find in certain movies.  In generally I really enjoyed my time playing 'Only If' and I recommend anyone at least give it a try.

I played this game for a total of probably 30 minutes. I can honestly say no, just no. People talk about the visual graphics in the game as if they're something to be praised, well they're not and you're mistaken. They put no time or effort into it. People comment on how the story is so engaging, I felt like the first impression I got was 'Hey man, are you here for a story that will grab your attention? Well keep on looking because we have no idea wtf we're doing here and we had a 5 year old write out the plot for you' The game is linear, as well as poorly constructed. It's a clicking simulator, and provides no objection what so ever. Sure I'll press [space] and [e] for 3 million years and finally realize that I'm supposed to be progressing forward. I guess the point of the game is to...  1. Install. 2. Play for a grand total of 20-30 minutes.  3. Uninstall. 4. Try to find something better.   I thought this game was going to be somewhat similar to Stanley's Parabole but no. It's nothing but a huge waste of time.   0/10 Would not recommend to an autistic hippo.  Stupid.

Vinnie was the best part of Only If; he seemed to come straight out of Borderlands and his mad cackling was a delight. That was the only part of the game that actually felt interesting or surreal. I REALLY wish 5.1 sound had been used, though. The dumb Bro you play would have been better off subtitled than voiced, and it wouldn't have killed the dev to at least give you some feet. Pants too, maybe, unless it's king of no pants day.  So one of the only things I hate more than not letting you change controls is giving an option to change controls, and then completely ignoring it. Not including half of the buttons it uses counts against the game too, but it doesn't matter anyway. I hated the controls but tried to get through for the game's sake.  The graphics are there, I guess. A few scenes are quite well done, most are just phoned in to get the job done, but it's enough for an indie.  The plot and puzzles suck. I just gave up after a while, the game didn't actually have puzzles so much as it just keeps ♥♥♥♥ing with you until you get sick of it, especially when it makes you repeat tedious levels over. and over. and over. And when it ran out of puzzles, it turned to first-person platforming, that was a facepalm. The plot is just, 'dude, wait, what?' repeated, it never seems to go anywhere. I'd like to see the ending, but I'll probably just watch someone else suffer for it on Youtube.  I could deal with a thin plot to string together good gameplay, or bad gameplay for a great story, but I didn't see either.  Good ideas though, I hope someone else does something great with them.

I find this game's love/hate is defined by two groups: people who hate cursing and abstract puzzles with very subtle hints at best, and people who love an undeniably unique atmosphere paired with exceptional vocal performances. Only If plays like the Talos Principle as designed by an OG beatnik. Trapped in an oddly beautiful and deeply psychological universe you're constantly taunted by a foul-mouthed stranger who serves as a powerful and genre-bending contrast to a backdrop of gigantic roman pillars, floating amethysts, antique wardrobes, a gorgeous park, and more vases than a single house should ever contain.  Only If's presentation is a one-of-a-kind experience backed by consistently good voice acting, particularly from the exasperated main character who just wants to get the hell out of there. The puzzles weren't as hard as many of the reviews seem to suggest, provided you take everything your seemingly mad companion says into account. The only time I got really stuck was in the park. Just remember that you can type answers to yes/no questions (with a couple of exceptions).  I've only taken the white pawn path thus far, and I'm definitely going to go for the second one as things evidently change a lot.  If you want a unique dreamlike experience, or the concept of an adult Boondocks style Alice in Wonderland story intrigues you, then go for it. I wasn't disappointed.
amazing graphics, immersive, complex, and challenging. five stars for real.

Having fully completed this game, I now would say that the game was a disappointment.   It began on a path of mystery, where the 'Voice' was our main form of exposition and the player needed to solve riddles and puzzles to further digress along the plot. However, as you get into the riddles of the white pawn (save the girl) they become more of a hallucinogen-like drug trip than a fantastical riddle/puzzle. The black pawn scenario (save yourself) reveals more about the plot outside of the riddles, while still giving puzzles and mazes for the player to solve. Although the black pawn scenario goes against most of our human nature in terms of choices, it is the better option for gameplay and plot.    The mechanics of the game are smooth and feel natural when playing. The proportion of objects is normal size, and doen't make the main character seem too small or too big for the world around him.    The idea behind the game is not new. I remember having the same feelings playing this game as I did playing Myst, an older, better and well planned puzzle/riddle game. The only difference with Only If is that I found myself constantly going online for playthroughs and solutions to the puzzles due to poorly designed hints and puzzle design.    The characters were interesting, and made me want to play the game to find out more about their stories, but there is a continuity error in the plot from the White Pawn and the Black Pawn. This needs to be fixed for the players who play the game for the achievements.    The achievements needed to be more vague, due to the fact that I found myself easily accomplishing the tasks neccessary to get them. It felt more like a numb agreement more than a hard earned success.    I hope to see this game developed further due to it's potential, but right now, it is not ready. If you want to play it, go ahead, but I would wait until the game is improved.

Just a foreword, but I played this right around when it first came out, before I started doing reviews. I however watched a YouTuber play this game recently which gave me the idea to actually write a review.  I played this as my very first horror game, and before I get further, it's not really scary (and I jump easily) but it does mess with your mind. As I played through it, I became very confused very quickly and so I used a walkthrough to progress through the game. This is my main reason why I don't recommend the game. I tried playing without the walkthrough for awhile, but it took literally a few minutes or so before I pulled it back up again. Grant it, I don't play many puzzle games, and I still don't really, but even through my stupidity I could tell these puzzles were a little out there.  Storywise, it made little sense to me. It also seemed to confuse the YouTuber I was watching play it. Few things make sense, BUT BUT BUT, if the devs for this game intended for that then they did do a good job. Only If is an interesting game, which puts you into horrific, beautiful and abstract places. It has not much content and is easily beaten in a few hours or even less, but than again, it's free. It has a couple of bugs and isn't optimized that good, so you may have some framedrops even on a decent PC. If you are into something weird, try it.
